Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 53177-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
October 2019 
 
 
Partnership with the Private Sector for  
Sustainable Trade Facilitation Results in the  
Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
Program 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  AEO  –  authorized economic operator 
  BCP  –  border crossing point 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
  CCC  –  CAREC Customs Cooperation Committee 
  CFCFA  –  CAREC Federation of Carrier and Forwarder Associations 
  CPMM  –  corridor performance measurement and monitoring 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  Ahmed M. Saeed, Operations 2 
Director General  Amy S. P. Leung, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Director  Xiaoqin Fan, Public Management, Financial Sector, and Regional 
Cooperation Division, EARD 
   
Team leader  Rosalind McKenzie, Senior Regional Cooperation Specialist, EARD 
Team members  Bernadette De Castro, Project Analyst, EARD 
  Desi Arvin Diaz, Associate Project Analyst, EARD 
  Zulfia Karimova, Principal Regional Cooperation Specialist, EARD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  strengthen  partnership 
mechanisms and working relationships between public and private stakeholders of the Central 
Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Program, with the aim of developing integrated 
and business-friendly transport and trade networks.1 The TA will continue to provide opportunities 
for greater private sector engagement in and contribution to effective trade facilitation in CAREC 
member countries, strengthen private sector institutions and capacity, and contribute to a better 
understanding of current logistics services and behind-the-border issues that hinder trade.2 
 
2.  The TA is aligned with CAREC long-term strategic priorities for trade as an operational 
cluster,3 and Asian Development Bank (ADB) regional cooperation and integration operational 
directions for 2016–2020.4 It supports objectives of the CAREC Integrated Trade Agenda 2030,5 
particularly the expansion of trade by adopting more open trade policies and building customs-to-
business cooperation, and the strengthening of institutions for trade via increased public–private 
sector dialogue and cooperation.6 
 
II.  ISSUES  
 
3.  CAREC countries’ share of global trade remains low at less than 1.0%, despite proximity 
to major trading partners and significant investment in connectivity infrastructure.7 The region still 
struggles  with  inadequate  border  infrastructure,  topographic  challenges,  nonphysical  trade 
barriers such as the lack of regional coherence in logistics and standards, and weak institutional 
capacity to facilitate efficient transport and trade of goods: in 2018, eight CAREC countries ranked 
in the bottom half of the World Bank’s Logistics Performance Index.8 The slow uptake of modern 
technologies and trade-related solutions, such as national electronic single windows, hinders 
efficient trade flow. CAREC corridor performance measurement and monitoring (CPMM) data 
show that less effective transit and border procedures cause bottlenecks at border-crossing points 
(BCPs), that delay trade and raise costs for business throughout the region:9 during 2010-2018, 
the average road BCP crossing time increased by 47% to 12 hours, off-set only slightly by a 9.0% 
drop in costs to clear the BCP.10 An incomplete understanding of transport, logistics, and behind-
the-border value-chain issues in the region further constrains effective cross-border and transit 
trade. Although these challenges directly impact private sector trade, CAREC countries have not 
 
1  The CAREC Program is a partnership of 11 countries—Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz 
Republic, Mongolia, Pakistan, the People’s Republic of China (PRC), Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan—and 
development partners, working together to accelerate economic growth and poverty reduction. CAREC Program. 
2  ADB has supported similar TA promoting private sector development and participation in CAREC trade facilitation: 
including ADB. Regional: Integrated Trade Facilitation Support for Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation; and 
ADB. Regional: Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation: Working with the Private Sector in Trade Facilitation. 
3  ADB. 2017. CAREC 2030: Connecting the Region for Shared and Sustainable Development. Manila. 
4  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila; and ADB. 2016. Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020: Promoting 
Connectivity, Competitiveness, Regional Public Goods, and Collective Action for Asia and the Pacific. Manila.  
5  ADB. 2018. CAREC Integrated Trade Agenda 2030 and Rolling Strategic Action Plan, 2018–2020. Manila. 
6  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 12 August 2019. 
7  CAREC member countries contribute less than 1.0% (excluding the PRC, which accounts for 11.5%) of the global 
trade share. World Trade Organization. Statistics database (accessed 13 September 2018). Data exclude the PRC. 
8  World Bank. 2018. Logistics Performance Index 2018. Washington. D.C. 
9  ADB. 2017. Trade Facilitation and Better Connectivity for an Inclusive Asia and Pacific. Manila; CAREC CPMM 
annual reports, 2009–2016. The CPMM mechanism is a results management tool that evaluates trade facilitation 
efficiency, publishing annual reports from the CAREC region.  
10  CAREC. 2018. CPMM Annual Report 2017. Manila.

2 
yet established adequate institutional mechanisms that enable private sector experience to 
contribute systematically to the identification of potential solutions.  
 
4.  With the support of ADB and development partners, CAREC customs and trade-related 
agencies are developing regulatory and operational frameworks to facilitate trade and build 
modern customs administrations.11 However, effective and sustainable facilitation is only possible 
with the strong involvement of trade-related private sector representation in policy dialogue and 
operations, to share private sector experience and evaluation. Business-to-customs interaction 
requires a robust enabling environment to  enable private sector contribution to policy and 
regulatory reform. As CAREC governments develop customs-to-business initiatives such as 
compliance programs, including authorized economic operator (AEO) programs,12 much stronger 
partnership with the private sector client base is key to sustainable implementation and success. 
Lack of opportunities to encourage public–private coordination in policy formulation as well as 
inadequate collaboration in operations has led to an environment of segmented transport and 
trade networks, where public and private sectors work in parallel—rather than together—to find 
solutions to the transport and trade challenges they all face. 
 
5.  The ADB-supported CAREC Federation of Carrier and Forwarder Associations (CFCFA) 
seeks to increase private sector engagement in trade facilitation, enhancing cooperation between 
public and private trade-related entities across the region.13 ADB TA support to the CFCFA has 
provided a voice to private sector transport and trade stakeholders through participation in (i) 
CAREC Ministerial Conferences, Senior Officials’ Meetings, and joint meetings with the CAREC 
Customs Cooperation Committee (CCC) to build public-private collaboration on trade facilitation 
reform; and (ii) business development forums. Supply chain and trade logistics trainings have 
strengthened operational understanding of regulators and operators, and helped the CFCFA start 
developing common logistics operational standards for the CAREC region to minimize the time 
and cost of cargo transshipment and cross-border transport. CAREC customs agencies have 
benefited from greater client interaction and evaluation of private sector experience at BCPs 
through the CPMM. Despite ADB support to the CFCFA, the organization has yet to develop into 
a fully independent operational entity. Assessment of previous TA support has recommended 
adopting a solutions-oriented approach focused on realistic shorter-term targets alongside longer-
term goals to stimulate private sector engagement and effective collective action in the CFCFA.14  
 
6.  CPMM data constitute (i) a unique measurement of trade facilitation along the CAREC 
transport corridors, and (ii) the basis of cross-country analyses that identify BCPs and CAREC 
corridor  sections  where  time-  and  cost-related  bottlenecks  are  most  prevalent,  and  where 
feasibility studies for investment are most urgent. The current focus of CPMM reports on transit 
and border procedures informs customs officials and policy makers, as well as traders and freight 
 
11  ADB. Regional: Implementing the Integrated Trade Agenda in the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
Program; ADB. Regional: Better Customs for Better Client Services in Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
Countries (forthcoming); ADB. Regional: Implementation of Trade Facilitation Initiatives in Central Asia Regional 
Economic Cooperation Program. 
12  World Customs Organization trusted trader and AEO programs offer the opportunity for customs agencies to share 
security responsibilities with private sector operators, and reward private sector AEO participants with additional 
trade facilitation benefits. World Customs Organization. AEO Compendium. 
13  The CFCFA works to (i) strengthen regional private sector institutional capacity, boosting its ability to inform and 
influence policy makers by facilitating public–private dialogue; (ii) help drive business-to-customs and customs-to-
business innovation; and (iii) promote transparency: CAREC Federation of Carrier and Forwarder Associations.  
14  ADB. 2014. Technical Assistance Completion Report: Integrated Trade Facilitation Support for CAREC. Manila; and 
ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance Completion Report: Working with the Private Sector in Trade Facilitation in 
CAREC. Manila.

3 
forwarders, about key issues that impede fast and reliable trade in the region and that contribute 
to estimating potential trade gains in CAREC (footnote 9). Guided by CPMM data and analysis 
for 2010-2017, ADB has financed three BCP improvement projects in four CAREC countries.15 
Under the TA, the CPMM scope will be expanded to contribute more comprehensively to policy 
formulation by including more detailed analysis of behind-the-border issues such as structural 
reforms and standards agencies, sanitary and phytosanitary laboratory capacity, and trade 
facilitation regulations. Given its success in effective monitoring of national trade facilitation efforts 
and its evidence-based contributions to policy, the CPMM is ready to be implemented and 
disseminated to a wider public and private sector audience in the CAREC region. As such, a 
partnership will be implemented between ADB and the CAREC Institute to transfer data gathering 
and management of the CPMM to the CAREC Institute. Under the TA, ADB and the CAREC 
Institute will jointly prepare and implement a CPMM roadmap to guide this transition and to include 
required capacity building to the CAREC Institute.  
 
7.  At the Fifth Joint Meeting of the CAREC CCC and the CFCFA, CAREC customs agencies 
and CFCFA members requested ADB to continue support for joint activities, particularly relating 
to the development and application of compliance programs.16 Customs agencies requested ADB 
to  facilitate  collaboration  with  CFCFA  national  associations  as  they  enhance  CPMM  data 
gathering, and to expand the CPMM mechanism to include deeper and wider analysis of behind-
the-border  trade-related  barriers.  The  annual  meeting  of  the  CAREC  Transport  Sector 
Coordinating Committee expressed a desire to coordinate more closely with the CFCFA and 
contribute to CPMM data gathering and analysis.17 The CFCFA, CCC, and CAREC Transport 
Sector Coordinating Committee also requested ADB to develop public domain digital database 
systems for CPMM data dissemination. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: (i) trade among CAREC countries and with 
global markets via CAREC corridors expanded (footnote 3); and (ii) linkages between public and 
trade-related private sector strengthened (footnote 5). The TA will have the following outcome: 
integrated and business-friendly transport and trade public–private sector linkages enhanced.18 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
  
9.  Output 1: Private sector involvement in trade facilitation expanded. To strengthen 
operational linkages between public and private sectors in CAREC countries, the TA will (i) 
continue support for joint public–private advocacy for national authorized economic operator 
programs that offer beneficial simplified customs processes and procedures, building strong 
partnerships from the start through consultative dialogue between the CAREC CCC and CFCFA 
platforms; (ii) support specific components of the wider private sector initiative to develop industry-
 
15  Regional border services improvement projects coordinate infrastructure  improvements and border crossing 
clearance procedures in the Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia, Pakistan, and Tajikistan. ADB. Regional: Central Asia 
Regional  Economic  Cooperation  Regional  Improvement  of  Border  Services  Project  (Kyrgyz  Republic  and 
Tajikistan); ADB. Pakistan: Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Regional Improving Border Services 
Project; and ADB. Mongolia: Regional Improvement of Border Services. 
16  CAREC. 2019. Fifth Joint Meeting of the CAREC Customs Cooperation Committee and CAREC Federation of 
Carriers and Forwarder Associations. Tashkent. 21 June. 
17  CAREC. 2019. 18th CAREC Transport Sector Coordinating Committee Meeting. Tashkent. 25–26 April. 
18  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
led standards on e-commerce, shipping container dimensions, telecommunication protocols, and 
help accelerate agreement on and adoption of CAREC-wide standards that minimize the time and 
cost of cargo transshipment and cross-border transport; and (iii) build deeper cooperation through 
regular interaction between the private sector and customs administrations to enable information 
exchange and streamline trade-related regulations and procedures to shape an open transport, 
trade, and trade facilitation regulatory environment. 
 
10.  Output 2: Institutional capacity of CFCFA strengthened. The TA will support design 
and initial implementation of a comprehensive business model for self-sustainability, including 
effective mobilization of member resources, and coordination of training opportunities amongst 
members, to help the CFCFA transition to a fully independent self-governing body by 2021. It will 
also support supplementary institutional strengthening and capacity building of the CFCFA to help 
it  develop  further  as  an  effective  autonomous  mechanism  to  improve  transport  and  trade 
facilitation. The TA will help design training and reference materials in foreign trade development, 
export or logistics for future practitioners to maintain and sustain sharing of knowledge and best 
practice among CFCFA members.19 Training activities will be conducted in collaboration with the 
CAREC Institute, the International Federation of Freight Forwarders Associations, the ADB 
Regional Knowledge Sharing Initiative, and relevant international agencies.20 
 
11.  Output 3: Sustainable institutional arrangement for CPMM implemented. The TA will 
help expand CPMM data gathering coverage to include trade logistics services and levels of 
compliance. Improved understanding of how logistics services are provided to the private sector 
and other stakeholders will contribute to valuable inputs for policy formulation and action. The 
enhanced CPMM will identify necessary complementarities in the regulations, procedures, and 
soft and hard infrastructure required among transit nations to improve efficiencies in transporting 
goods along the corridors and across borders. Results will be published in CPMM annual reports. 
Based on 10 years of CPMM data, a flagship report will be prepared to (i) identify progress in 
trade facilitation measures in the CAREC region, through analysis of trends in time, cost, and 
distance indicators; and (ii) provide policy recommendations. An electronic interface will be 
developed for the CPMM database to provide public access to CPMM data. ADB and the CAREC 
Institute will form a partnership to produce flagship knowledge products, based on CPMM data. 
A CPMM roadmap will be prepared to facilitate the transition of CPMM data gathering and 
management to the CAREC Institute, to ensure wider dissemination, use, and application of 
CPMM data; and CPMM annual reports will be prepared jointly by ADB and the CAREC Institute. 
 
12.  TA outputs will be disseminated electronically to public and private sector stakeholders, 
through the ADB and CAREC websites, and as CAREC conference and workshop materials. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000 equivalent, which will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund.21 The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2. The Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund will finance operational expenses 
such as consulting services and related goods and activities; it will not be used to finance (i) civil 
works, (ii) procurement of large-scale equipment, or (iii) permanent staffing costs. 
 
19  Training curriculum will complement and update the training provided to CFCFA members supported by ADB TA 
7353 and 6437 to adopt industry best practice and promote wider application among member associations. 
20  ADB–PRC Regional Knowledge Sharing Initiative. The Government of the PRC and ADB established the program 
in 2012 to facilitate the exchange of development-related knowledge among ADB’s developing member countries. 
21  Established by ADB. Financing partner: the Government of Japan.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB’s East Asia Regional Department (EARD) will be the 
implementing  agency  and  will  supervise  activities  including  public–private  sector  dialogue, 
workshops, and conferences; and the selection and management of consultants and resource 
persons. EARD will work closely with (i) the CAREC Institute and the Regional Knowledge 
Sharing Initiative; (ii) the CAREC unit and the CAREC transport sector; and (iii) ADB resident 
missions in CAREC countries to create synergies among regional initiatives; and will provide staff 
to serve as resource persons for TA-funded activities. The implementation arrangements are 
summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  October 2019–March 2021 
Executing agency  ADB 
Implementing agency  ADB’s East Asia Department will implement the TA in coordination with the 
CAREC Institute, RKSI, ADB’s Central and West Asia Department, and ADB 
resident missions in CAREC countries. 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
Individual selection  International expertise  $263,674 
(14.5 person-months) 
Individual selection  National expertise   $91,372 
(34.5 person-months) 
Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, CAREC = Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program, RKSI = Regional 
Knowledge Sharing Initiative, TA = technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.22 ADB will select individual consultants to provide a total of 14.5 person-
months of international consultancy, 34.5 person-months of national consultancy, and resource 
person inputs. ADB will recruit consultants individually rather than through a firm because (i) the 
wide range of experience, expertise, and specific knowledge of the CAREC Program and CFCFA 
activities required to complete all TA activities is not available in a single firm; and (ii) consultants 
and resource persons should be mobilized rapidly. Where appropriate, output-based contracts 
will be considered for consulting services under the TA. ADB will be responsible for management 
oversight and monitoring of consultants during TA implementation. The TA cost estimates in 
Appendix 2 are indicative, and estimates will be finalized before the approval of each activity. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
the Partnership with the Private Sector for Sustainable Trade Facilitation Results in the Central 
Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
22  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Private sector involvement in trade facilitation expanded 
1.1  Conduct needs assessment study on private sector capacity and willingness to participate in customs’ compliance 
programs; CFCFA and CCC to prepare joint action plan on compliance program initiative (by March 2021) 
1.2  Conduct studies with CFCFA members and other trade-related private sector entities to identify trade facilitation 
constraints and solutions (by December 2020) 
1.3  Analyze results of studies and draft policy recommendations for presentation to the joint CCC–CFCFA meeting (by 
February 2021) 
1.4  Establish permanent CFCFA working group to follow up and monitor recommendations (May 2020) 
1.5  Conduct gap analysis to determine national and/or regional acceptance and adoption of industry-initiated standards 
(by August 2020) 
1.6  Commission  official  translation  of  specific  CFCFA-developed  standards  into  Russian;  facilitate  electronic 
publication in the Russian, English, and Mandarin languages; and disseminate to CFCFA members (by November 
2020)  
1.7  Support the annual meeting of the CFCFA and joint meeting of the CFCFA and CCC (May 2020) 
2.  Institutional capacity of CFCFA strengthened 
2.1  Design  and  facilitate  training  materials  among  CFCFA  members  to  provide  assistance  to  other  CFCFA 
associations and future logistics and freight forwarding practitioners (by October 2020) 
2.2  Draft  manuals  and/or  compendiums  of  trade  logistics  practices  (with  translation)  in  CAREC  countries  in 
collaboration with relevant CFCFA members and other research institutions (by March 2021) 
2.3  Develop business model and action plan for self-sustainability of the CFCFA; initiate implementation of business 
model action plan (by March 2021) 
3.  Sustainable institutional arrangement for CPMM implemented 
3.1  Roll out the expanded CPMM, capturing barriers related to trade logistics services (by February 2020) 
3.2  Prepare and publish CPMM reports (semiannual and annual through 2020) 
3.3  Prepare and publish a CPMM flagship report to identify progress in trade facilitation measures in the CAREC region 
(by November 2020) 
3.4  Establish formal partnership with CAREC Institute for CPMM data gathering and management, with CPMM annual 
reports developed jointly by ADB and the CAREC institute; develop and implement the CPMM roadmap, including 
capacity building program and 5-year resource mobilization plan (by March 2021) 
3.5  Develop a public domain electronic interface for the CPMM database, in collaboration with the CAREC Institute 
  (by March 2021) 
TA Management Activities 
Conduct supervision missions to assess progress of the TA; consult with the private sector to ensure smooth 
implementation of the TA; provide technical and administrative guidance to ensure efficient implementation of the TA; 
develop operational partnership with the CAREC Institute and provide required capacity building 
Inputs 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Fundc: $750,000 
Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Not applicable.

Cooperation Committee, CFCFA = CAREC Federation of Carrier and Forwarders Associations, CPMM = corridor 
performance measurement and monitoring, PRC = People’s Republic of China, RFI = results framework indicator, TA 
= technical assistance.

RFI B: Regional or subregional mechanisms created or operationalized to enhance coordination and cooperation 
among DMCs in trade, finance, or multisector economic corridors. Expected: 1.
